courses_list.course_description: The Fundamentals of Programming with Code.org course is an entry-level class for K-1st graders. No experience is necessary for this class. Code.org is an easy-to-use platform that teaches fundamental programming concepts. Students will need internet access, paper, and a writing utensil.

Basic Scratch Part 1 (2-3) is the first part of a two-part course introducing the Scratch platform to 2nd and 3rd graders. Scratch is a popular visual block-based programming language developed by the MIT Media Lab. No experience is necessary for this class. Students need internet access and a personal device (preferably computer).

Basic Scratch Part 2 (2-3) is the second part of a two-part course introducing the Scratch platform to 2nd and 3rd graders. Students should have taken Basic Scratch Part 1 before taking this class.  Scratch is a popular visual block-based programming language developed by the MIT Media Lab. Students need internet access and a personal device (preferably computer)

S﻿cratch (4-6) is an entry-level course introducing students to the Scratch platform, a popular block-based programming language developed by the MIT Media Lab. Students do not need prior experience with programming. Students will need an internet connection and a personal device (preferably computer).

C﻿omputer-Aided Design (CAD) with Tinkercad introduces students in 5th-8th grades to the basics of computer-aided design using Tinkercad, a simple web-based platform. Students do not need prior experience or knowledge of CAD. Students will need internet access and a personal device (preferably computer).

W﻿eb Design with HTML/CSS (6-8) introduces students in 6th-8th grades to how websites are developed. HTML provides structure to a website, and CSS provides style. Students do not need previous experience or knowledge of web development. Students will need an internet connection and a computer.

**Overview**

* Python (6-8) is designed for students in grades 6th-8th who do not have any prior experience with the Python coding language. 
* ​Python is a professional coding language widely used by many companies, including Wikipedia, Google, and Facebook. This course is designed to teach students the basics of Python.

**Who should take this course?**

* 6th-8th Graders with no or minimal experience with Python. 

  * Please reference the topic overview section and see what concepts the student knows. If the student only knows 1-3 of the topics, this course will still be challenging enough.
* 4th-5th Graders with some prior experience in programming in Scratch, or another language.

**Who shouldn’t take this course?**

* K-3rd Graders.

  * These students should take Fundamentals of Programming with Code.org (K-1) or Basic Scratch (2-3).
* 4th-5th Graders who have never taken a programming course. 

  * These students should take Scratch (4-6).
* 6th-8th Graders with extensive Python experience. 

  * These students should take Java (6-8).

**Topic Overview**

* Syntax
* Calculator
* Variables and Types
* Lists
* Conditional Logic  and Loops
* String Operations and Formatting
* Functions

**Class Structure**

1. 10-30 minute video lesson.
2. First class meeting: 1 hour video call
3. Homework (1- 2 hours) 
4. Second class meeting: 1 hour video call

**Curriculum Goals**

* Students should master all the fundamentals of Python and programming in general. 
* Students should have a better baseline for other written coding languages such as Java.

**Overview**

* Java (6-8) is designed for students grades 6th-8th who do not have any prior experience with the Java coding language.
* Java is a professional coding language widely used by many companies. This course is designed to teach students the basics of Java.
* This class is designed for students without any prior experience with Java, so students with prior experience may find the class to be initially too slow. 

**Who should take this course?**

* 6th-8th Graders with none or minimal experience with Java.

  * Please reference the topic overview section and see what concepts the student knows. If the student only knows 1-3 of the topics, this course will still be challenging enough.
* 4th-5th Graders with some prior experience in programming in Scratch, or another language.

**Who shouldn’t take this course?**

* K-3rd Graders.

  * These students should take a more beginner course such as Fundamentals of Programming with Code.org (K-1) or Basic Scratch (2-3).
* 4th-5th Graders who have never taken a programming course. 
* * These students should take Scratch (4-6).
* 6th-8th Graders with extensive Java experience. 

  * Please review the topic overview below to see what topics are covered in this class.

**Topic Overview**

* Syntax
* Data Types
* Print Statements
* Variables
* Math Operators
* Conditional statements (if, else, else if, switch)
* Loops (while, for)
* Arrays
* String Methods
* Static Methods
* 2D Arrays
* Classes and Objects
* Hashmaps
* ArrayLists
* File and User Input
* Math class, random class

**W﻿eekly Class Structure**

1. First class meeting: 1 hour video call
2. Homework (1- 2 hours) 
3. Second class meeting: 1 hour video call
4. Homework (1- 2 hours) 

**Curriculum Goals**

* Students should master all the fundamentals of Java and programming in general.
* Students should have a better baseline for other written coding languages such as C and C++.
